column4: electricity generation via direct conversion of solar energy into electrical energy using photovoltaic (PV) cells, or via indirect conversion of sunlight into electricity using mirrors that concentrate sunlight into a solar receiver, and integration into a PV system that also includes mounting structures and/or building-integrated PV (BIPV), inverters, and battery storage; concentrated solar power system is a type of thermal power station
column5: DOE Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Solar Energy Technologies Office (SETO): https://www.energy.gov/eere/solar/solar-photovoltaic-system-design-basics
column6:
To the greatest extent practicable, procure low-impact PV arrays to heat water for buildings, minimizing the adverse effects on topsoil, plants, and wildlife.

Maximize the value of PV systems and associated battery storage by: 1) energy arbitrage or decreasing demand for to lower utility bills and 2) dispatch the systems in response to demand to generate revenue, and 3) use as back-up power to support mission critical operations during outages (https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/articles/considerations-implementing-pv-plus-storage-systems-federal-buildings-and)

Optimize PV system size and dispatch strategy using available federal tools, such as DOE National Renewable Energy Laboratory's (NREL's) Renewable Energy Integration and Optimization (REopt) platform (https://reopt.nrel.gov).

column4: capture and use of geothermal heat (generally 300F to 700F); electricity generation via conversion of geothermal heat into electrical energy using heated working fluid to turn turbines, and integration with generators and production and injection wells, reservoirs, control systems, and other components; type of thermal power station
column6:
Strongly consider including geothermal energy as part of the agency energy portfolio if the agency is located in the western states of the U.S. or Hawaii, where most geothermal power plants are located (https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/geothermal/where-geothermal-energy-is-found.php)

Prioritize procurements from direct use heating systems and geothermal heat pumps rather than from geothermal power plants to minimize carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide emissions ( https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/geothermal/use-of-geothermal-energy.php)

Favor natural gas over coal and distillate fuel oil because its combustion produces comparatively  less carbon dioxide for an equal amount of energy (https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/natural-gas/natural-gas-and-the-environment.php)

Consider wood gas, which is derived from wood or other biomass, a means for heating and powering motors in place of fossil fuels in scenarios where large storage volumes are possible. Wood gas requires comparatively larger storage volumes due to its lower heat of combustion.

column4: electricity generation via conversion of heat energy from nuclear fission, occurring and contained in reactor cores, into electrical energy using a combination of steam turbines, generators, condensers, cooling and control systems, and containment buildings; type of thermal power station
column6:
Since the license of the Yucca Mountain repository expired in 2010, disposal of commercial spent nuclear fuel presents a growing challenge, as it is often stored on-site and can pose serious threats to human health and the environment. Therefore, before procuring nuclear power, carefully examine how and where the power plant manages its nuclear waste (https://www.gao.gov/products/gao-21-603)

Especially in areas that lack sufficient or suitable land for solar, wind, hydroelectric, and geothermal power, strongly consider nuclear power as a viable alternative. According to DOE, "A typical 1,000-megawatt nuclear facility in the United States needs a little more than 1 square mile to operate. NEI says wind farms require 360 times more land area to produce the same amount of electricity and solar photovoltaic plants require 75 times more space." (https://www.energy.gov/ne/articles/3-reasons-why-nuclear-clean-and-sustainable).

column6:
Where practicable and where supported by the local tribe, consider supporting the development of sustainable data centers and associated clean energy projects on Native American reservations. Consider engagement with federal programs to bolster these efforts, such as the Tribal Energy Loan Guarantee Program (https://www.energy.gov/lpo/tribal-energy-loan-guarantee-program).

On matters related to the development of sustainable data centers, prioritize engagement with Native American tribes that have Tribal Energy Resource Agreements (TERAs) and Tribal Energy Development Organizations (TEDOs) (https://www.bia.gov/service/tribal-energy-resource-agreements-development-organizations)

column4: work arrangements in which employees perform their duties and fulfill their responsibilities at an employer-approved location; routine visits to the employer worksite each pay period refers to telework; no routine visits to the employer worksite each pay period refers to remote work.
column6:
Federal agencies should emphasize telework and remote work for data center operations to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and other greenhouse gas emissions associated with employee travel, and reduce the energy needed for lighting and temperature regulation.

Furthermore, federal procurements of data center services are encouraged to include contract language that emphasizes the maximum practicable amount of telework and remote work for these same reasons.

column6: To reduce transportation-related energy consumption, locate the development of data centers near public transportation hubs. Further incentivize use of public transportation via public transportation subsidies to data center staff through already-existing program such as TRANServe (https://www.transportation.gov/transerve). For data center staff who are contractors rather than federal employees, consider including contract provisions that require such subsidies or other public transportation benefits.

column1: turning off failover servers until needed
column4: power down failover servers, or backup servers that automatically turn on if the primary server cannot be accessed, until primary server cannot be accessed.
column6: Failover servers should be powered down until primary servers fail to reduce energy consumption and save on electricity costs.
column7: 42 U.S.C. § 8253(b): http://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?hl=false&edition=2012&req=granuleid%3AUSC-prelim-title42-section8253&f=treesort&fq=true&num=0

column4: recommended temperature or temperature range for inlet air or liquid into IT equipment
column6:
To reduce cooling energy consumption and save on electricity costs, consider using inlet temperatures that approach the upper threshold of the recommended temperature or temperature range, which varies according to the cooling method (air or liquid) and environmental class (A1, A2, A3, A4, or H1 for air-cooled; W16, W27, W32, W40, W45, orW+ for liquid-cooled). See the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE's) 2021 Equipment Thermal Guidelines for Data Processing Environments: https://www.ashrae.org/File%20Library/Technical%20Resources/Bookstore/Supplemental%20Files/ReferenceCard_2021ThermalGuidelines.pdf

Ensure that IT equipment stays within the recommended thermal envelope as defined by ASHRAE: https://www.techstreet.com/ashrae/standards/thermal-guidelines-for-data-processing-environments-5th-ed?product_id=2212974

Recommend air over liquid cooling.
column7: 42 U.S.C. § 8253(b): http://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?hl=false&edition=2012&req=granuleid%3AUSC-prelim-title42-section8253&f=treesort&fq=true&num=0

column4: flow of outside air or water to cool IT equipment within data center white space, reducing or circumventing the need for traditional cooling systems.
column6: To the maximum extent practicable, site new data centers in locations that will offer free cooling via air-side economizers and/or water-side economizers: https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/articles/best-practices-guide-energy-efficient-data-center-design. Regarding the potential use of air-side economizers, consider not just ambient temperature and humidity but also contaminants (e.g., particulate matter and gaseous pollutants).
column7: 42 U.S.C. § 8253(b): http://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?hl=false&edition=2012&req=granuleid%3AUSC-prelim-title42-section8253&f=treesort&fq=true&num=0

column4: rows of server racks with alternating and sufficiently isolated hot and cold aisles; the heat exhaust is located in the hot aisles, and the air intakes are located in the cold aisles.
column5: FEMP Best Practices Guide for Energy-Efficient Data Center Design: https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/articles/best-practices-guide-energy-efficient-data-center-design
column6:
Air from hot aises should be used as a heat source for water and other applications (temperature depending on intended use), thereby reducing or eliminating the need for electricity or gas for these purposes (https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/articles/best-practices-guide-energy-efficient-data-center-design). Concentrate IT equipment to increase the temperature of hot aisles.

Physically partition the space between hot and cold aisles with flexible or rigid materials to minimize mixing of hot and cold air, while still allowing for easy access to servers (https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/articles/best-practices-guide-energy-efficient-data-center-design).
column7: 42 U.S.C. § 8253(b): http://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?hl=false&edition=2012&req=granuleid%3AUSC-prelim-title42-section8253&f=treesort&fq=true&num=0
column8: FEMP Best Practices Guide for Energy-Efficient Data Center Design: https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/articles/best-practices-guide-energy-efficient-data-center-design

column4: real-time monitoring and control of data center energy consumption to optimize energy consumption and minimize electricity costs.
column6:
Leverage active energy management to determine and mitigate the underlying causes of high energy consumption. A key aspect of active energy management is re-tuning, a low-cost approach to managing federal buildings via the identification and correction of operational problems (https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/re-tuning-federal-buildings). Re-tuning typically reduces energy consumption between 5% and 25%.

Deploy an Energy Management Information System (EMIS) throughout your data center infrastructure to optimize energy consumption (https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/energy-management-information-systems-federal-facilities).

Procure data center services from those that have achieved DOE 50001 Ready recognition and/or DOE Superior Energy Performance 50001 (SEP 50001) (https://betterbuildingssolutioncenter.energy.gov/iso-50001/50001Ready; https://betterbuildingssolutioncenter.energy.gov/iso-50001/sep-50001).

column4: Comprehensive plan that outlines an agency's energy vision, mission, goals, objectives, performance metrics, strategies, and timelines for achieving these; integrates energy, budgetary/financial, and environmental considerations; and aligns with agency-wide strategic plan, including long-term strategic goals and strategic objectives.
column6: Your agency is encouraged to develop a detailed energy strategic plan that: 1) charts an efficient and measurable course between your agency's current and future energy state, 2) leverages renewable energy sources to the maximum extent practicable to power its operations (including both on-premise and off-premise IT), and 3) aligns with your larger agency strategic plan.

column1: on-site primary power production through non-traditional methods
column4: on-site conversion of primary energy (i.e., energy that has not already been converted off-site to electricity or another energy carrier) to electricity via solar, wind, geothermal, biopower, hydroelectric, tidal power, or other methods.
column6:
Your agency should explore purchasing renewable primary power generation via on-site contracts with third-party owners (https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/federal-site-electricity-contracts), which can translate into decreased energy costs, carbon emissions, and transmission loss.

To fund on-site primary power production via renewable energy sources, consider the benefits and drawbacks of Congressional appropriations as well as different contract vehicles as applicable to your agency: Energy Savings Performance Contracts, Energy Savings Performance Contract Energy Sales Agreements, Utility Energy Service Contracts, On-Site Electricity Purchase Contracts, Real Property Arrangements/Enhanced Use Leases (https://www.energy.gov/eere/femp/federal-site-distributed-energy-procurement-options#appropriations).

column4: location and commodity-dependent process of collection and processing of waste materials, and remanufacture of these into new new products
column6:
To the maximum extent practicable, construct and equip data centers that contain products created from recycled materials, such as recycled metal, glass, plastic, and paper, to limit the environmental impact caused by waste of old materials and manufacture of new materials.

Prioritize procurements of recycled materials that are listed in the Comprehensive Procurement Guideline (CPG) Program product directory (https://www.epa.gov/smm/comprehensive-procurement-guideline-cpg-program#products).

column1: thermal solar to heat water and people space
column4: process of collecting heat from absorbtion of sunlight usually via a solar thermal collector, and transferring of heat via working fluid-filled pipes for water and people space heating.
column6: To the maximum extent practicable, prioritize procurements of data centers and data center services that use thermal solar energy to heat water and people space, thereby reducing energy consumption, associated energy costs, and greenhouse gas emissions. Of the different types of solar thermal collectors to be used, consider honeycomb solar thermal collectors (HSTCs), which minimize heat loss and are 8% more efficient than flat-plate collectors (https://www.gsa.gov/cdnstatic/GPG_Findings_027-Honeycomb_Solar_Thermal_Collector.pdf).
